title: Tom Catena's work in a remote, war-torn region of Africa
content: Tom Catena, a missionary physician who runs Mother of Mercy Hospital in the Nuba Mountains in Sudan, describes some of his extraordinary work as the only doctor in a remote, war-torn region of Africa. In terms of individual lives saved, you could argue that there is no other person on the front lines doing more than Tom.

title: The Nuba people's cause of death
content: We explore the manner in which the Nuba people die, which is in striking contrast to the ubiquity of chronic disease and self-harm in the west, despite the extreme poverty and unimaginable suffering experienced by the Nuba people.

title: The resilience of the Nuba people
content: Lastly, we discuss the lessons to be gleaned from the Nuba people, who despite their suffering, live so harmoniously, happily, and resiliently.

title: How to support Mother of Mercy Hospital
content: You can support the Mother of Mercy Hospital by donating funds for an operating eye microscope and associated supplies, housing, batteries for solar panels, or to pay for a C-section. Each C-section costs roughly $250.

title: Background and early days of missionary work in Africa
content: Tom grew up in Amsterdam, New York, majored in mechanical engineering at Brown University, and went to medical school at Duke on a scholarship from the Navy. He worked at Our Lady of Lourdes Mutomo Hospital in the rural settlement of Mutomo, Kenya, where he saw 50-60 patients per day with a variety of diseases. He then moved to St Mary’s Mission Hospital in Nairobi, Kenya, where he worked with the Bishop of the El Obeid Diocese, Macram Gassis, to plan out the Sudan hospital in the Nuba Mountains.

title: The history of war within Sudan
content: Civil war going on for decades between north and south Sudan. Omar al-Bashir took power in 1989. North issued jihad against Nuba in the early 90s even though many of them are muslim but since they lived in harmony with christians they were not “true” muslim. This lead to a lot of genocide (led by Hassan Al-Turabi). Peace agreement signed in 2005. In 2011, the South voted to officially secede from the North. But Nuba was not included in south. It was separate but North wanted Nuba under their control. There was a sham election and al-Bashir’s candidate wins election. Civil war breaks out in Nuba against the government in June 2011.

title: Fighting starts
content: Fighting begins in June 2011 after Southern Sudan votes to secede. The war is between the North Sudan government and the people of Nuba which consisting of local tribes of Nuba plus some leftover South Sudan soldiers who still live in Nuba. This “new” military fighting against North Sudan was referred to as SPLA North (the South Sudan soldiers are simply “SPLA”)

title: The staff evacuates
content: A plane came, last plane for a long time, and staff had to decide whether to leave or stay. Had to secretly bring in plane bc N sudan would bomb them if saw them. Tom stayed. All other expats left. So now just Tom and local Nuba people.

title: Girl needing arm amputated
content: First case after staff evacuated. Girl came in needing her arm amputated. Neither Tom, nor the nurses knew how to do general anesthesia. They literally read a basic anesthesia book that listed it out step by step. Tom had to intubate the patient, which can kill them if done wrong, something Tom had never done before. By the grace of God, got the patient intubated. Then someone had to manually ventilate the patient throughout the entire surgery. All they had was an Oxford Miniature Ventilator.

title: Intussusception in a baby
content: Nine month old baby intussusception is when the intestine telescopes on itself and basically causes a blockage of the intestine. The longer you delay, that intestine can die and the person will die from infection. We made the diagnosis and I’m just like, ‘Oh God, what are we supposed to do with this kid?’ But managed to get baby intubated. Did a bowel resection. And now he’s nine years old, “he’s cruising”

title: Injuries from shrapnel
content: Liver lacerations, bowel injuries, hemopneumothorax, head trauma, kidney trauma, etc. One guy has 23 holes in his intestines that “we had to resect here, resect there, stitch this one… just took forever”

title: Patients that Tom is unable to save
content: How does Tom deal with telling families he can’t save someone? Nuba people have low expectations, they don’t expect miracles. They just want to be treated as a human, they want that human touch. As a people, they are very accepting of negative outcomes or bad news. This makes sense when you consider that they are largely living “at the edge of survival all the time”. They are also very spiritual.

title: Primitive care
content: Local traditions include: Burning ⇒ to try to release fevers, malaria, and other illness, the local tradition is to burn the skin to “release” the illness (All the Nuba people have burn marks). Some herbal remedies for malaria (not much evidence it is working).

title: Local remedies for GI problems
content: Local fruits and veggies for GI problems (works a little bit per Tom)

title: Delay in seeking medical attention due to local shamans
content: Local shamans⇒ Known as the “Kujur”, the shamans will visit the family and come up with a reason why a child may be sick (this unfortunately delays the time until they will see a real doctor)

title: Limited knowledge of the outside world among the Nuba people
content:
Very little
Example, Tom’s wife’s mother has lived entire life in her tribe in Nuba Mountains
She has never heard of the United States, thought Tom was from Kenya
No concept of an ocean
She didn’t even know she was in Africa
“A lot of my wife’s siblings have never been out of this 15 square mile radius. You can’t imagine the worldview.”

title: Peter's encounter with the Sudanese community
content:
Peter took the whole family to the Sudanese Community Center in San Diego to deliver Christmas gifts
Basically all refugees there
Peter’s youngest child (1.5 years) was playing with a similar-aged Sudanese child
There’s a woman that’s holding the Sudanese girl and she was sort of keeping an eye on Peter’s son as well
A few hours later they thank the young mother for watching their son, and turns out she wasn’t even related to the Sudanese child
“We couldn’t stop talking about that… talk about a different sense of community.” says Peter
“For as many things as they lack, they have something we don’t have.”

title: The amazing community of the Sudanese people
content:
Tom says: “You always hear about the negative side of a place like Sudan. . .war, poverty, disease, starving kids… but the positive side is not shown.”
“The concept of community, what stuff belongs to you, what does a stranger mean? … Totally different than our outlook here.”
Example,
Tom has patients travel by foot for days to get to the hospital
Along the way, they will just knock on the door of a stranger and that person will give them food and a place to stay

title: Tom's perspective on working in Nuba
content:
Tom says everybody has something to contribute
“I think everybody has something to offer and if we try to get in this thinking like, ‘Gosh, I’m not doing what he’s doing, I should be doing what he’s doing.’ I think we miss the point. We miss out on our shared abilities.”
“I think it’s good to be aware of what’s going on in the world and everybody should think about their brothers and sisters elsewhere and contribute and do something to help other people. At the same time don’t spend too much time stressing that you’re not doing enough. . . do something, but it shouldn’t be something which is agonizingly painful.”

title: Tom's work in Nuba Mountains
content: Nick Kristof learned about Tom through his interest in Sudan and made a couple of trips into the Nuba mountains. Tom's work in the region was highlighted by Kristof's article and video. Tom won the 2017 Aurora Prize for his work in Nuba and now works with Aurora as a chairman of the organization. The Aurora Prize gives away 1 million dollars yearly to people doing humanitarian work and allows them to elect which charity that money goes towards.

title: Aurora Prize organization
content: Aurora's focus is on highlighting unsung heroes who are operating in the weeds, that nobody knows about. Tom now works with Aurora as a chairman of the organization. The Aurora Prize gives away 1 million dollars yearly to people doing humanitarian work and allows them to elect which charity that money goes towards.

title: Logistics challenges
content: The biggest problem in the region is logistics. Supplies have to come from Nairobi which is 2 countries away. First, it goes through Uganda, up to the border with South Sudan where they just harass the heck out of the drivers.

title: Mortality of childbirth
content: Most neonatal deaths are just from difficult deliveries (baby gets asphyxiated, baby’s born and dies, either is a stillborn, or dies soon after birth). 99% of women there still deliver at home, but many of the infant deaths would have survived with a c-section.

title: Mortality of mothers
content: It’s likely pretty high because we have a lot of women that we end up doing C-sections on that would have died without that.

title: Challenges of the remote location of Nuba
content: Once had a measles epidemic and he was seeing 225 kids per day on top of everything else. They couldn’t get vaccines to Nuba because they were in rebel-territory. Tom’s Nuba hospital was bombed twice by the North Sudan military.

title: Bombing and Trauma
content: Tom describes the emotional trauma of living in a warzone and being constantly on call. He talks about the physical and mental exhaustion that comes with always being responsible for patients and not having a psychological rest. He also describes the terror of being bombed and the emotional trauma that comes with it.

title: Lack of Medical Equipment
content: Tom talks about the basic tools, technologies, and medicines that he lacks that could save many lives. He has an ultrasound and an x-ray machine, but his biggest challenge is lab work. His machines keep breaking down and he could really use a Piccolo lab machine, which costs roughly $14,000 and would need a year supply of discs for the machine.

title: Leukemia Treatment
content: Tom talks about the different types of leukemia and how he is able to treat chronic lymphocytic leukemia (CLL) with cyclophosphamide, which is pretty effective. However, he does not have a treatment for chronic myelocytic leukemia (CML), which is very treatable with the drug called Gleevec. It costs $7,000 per month, which is too expensive for Tom to spend knowing that $80,000 could save hundreds of lives. He has to make these agonizing decisions constantly.

title: CML Patient Needs Gleevec
content: Tom’s current patient (a mother with CML) desperately needs Gleevec. She’s got a huge spleen that hurts, she’s anemic, and she’s got a bunch of kids. Only a small amount of Gleevec would get her through the year. She is one of only a few people with CML so they really don’t need much.

title: Diseases in the Adult Population
content: Liver disease is high on the list, including cirrhosis and liver cancers (mostly from hepatitis B). Hepatitis B is very common. Diphtheria, leprosy, tuberculosis, and STDs are also prevalent. Congestive heart failure is seen in people in their 60s & 70s, and untreated hypertension is common. Obesity is almost non-existent, and Type 2 Diabetes and fatty liver disease are rare. The most common cancers in Nuba are liver cancer and cervical cancer in women.

title: Preventing Cervical Cancer through Screening
content: There is something called the See and treat technique. This might be a middle step before Gardasil becomes available. You first need the equipment and then you need the staff with the knowledge and it would be pretty labor intensive.

title: Breast Cancer
content: There are some cases. But nobody is getting a mammogram, so people are only diagnosed when they come in with a noticeable lump. Treatment in these women is pretty unsuccessful. Would getting a mammography machine help? Partially, but like cervical cancer, Tom would need a whole staff of people to read it… so the machine alone wouldn’t help much.

title: Colon Cancer
content: Very rare, 2 or 3 cases in 10 years. What is the average life span? Nobody knows their exact age (no birth certificates). They don’t celebrate their birthdays. Tom guesses they don’t live much longer than 70s.

title: Cognitive Impairment
content: Really rare, “they probably die of something else before they reach that stage”.

title: Diet in Nuba
content: The locals usually eat rice, kidney beans, some kind of lentils, and once in a while, chicken. The sorghum actually has a high protein level, and locals are actually pretty muscular. Fruits and veggies are seasonal, and milk is only available for a couple of months because the cows will only give birth during the rainy season. Since there’s no refrigeration, the milk is sour, curdled, and they will pour that over the assida, over the sorghum paste.

title: Tom's bout of malaria
content: Tom describes his annual bout of malaria as pretty bad, with symptoms including a real bad headache, nausea, vomiting, high fevers, body aches, and terrible body aches. A lot of times, it’ll drag on for a month, and Tom was even in a coma for a few days one year. He recovered pretty quickly, but it was a terrible experience.

title: Patients Tom will never forget
content: Tom describes several patients he will never forget, including a 10-year-old bombing victim who came in with bomb shrapnel in his face. He had first gone to another place that just stitched it up without proper cleaning, and it was completely infected. Another kid had third-degree burns from a napalm bomb, and six other burn victims lived in a village that should get shelled all day and bombed at night. A soldier with 23 holes in his abdomen died suddenly after many hours of operating on him.

title: Civilian victims of bombings
content: Peter shares an image of civilian victims who were ruthlessly bombed by the North Sudan government.

title: Resources for getting involved
content: Peter shares resources for people wanting to get involved in helping Tom's work, including the African Mission Healthcare Foundation, Take Heart Foundation, and Catholic Medical Mission Board.

title: The Starfish Story
content: Peter tells a story that defines Tom as someone working on the front lines, the Starfish Story, which Tom responds to by saying that medicine is individual and that it's a huge privilege to have the opportunity to affect one person.

title: Tom's impact
content: Peter sums up Tom's impact by saying that he throws more starfish back in the water than anyone else on the planet.
